Graphical abstract For realizing resource desulfurization and high-value sulfur recovery, an iron-loaded catalyst was prepared from steelmaking byproduct blast furnace slag to reduce SO2 to elemental sulfur with CO. SO2 conversion efficiency, sulfur selectivity, and sulfur yield were used to evaluate the catalyst behavior. The catalyst with 15wt.% Fe2O3 at 500 °C showed the best activity performance. The changes in the structure and active phase of the catalyst as well as the complete reaction pathway were explored. A series of in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy experiments were used to study the adsorption and desorption processes of CO and SO2, and a large number of sulfates were formed on the catalyst surface after the reaction. Combined with the experimental performance, the strong adsorption of BFS and the production pathway of H2S were proposed. The prepared iron-loaded catalysts followed the redox mechanism and the COS intermediate mechanism in the reaction. Keywords Blast furnace slag Iron-based catalyst Catalytic reduction sulfur dioxide Elemental sulfur 1 Introduction SO2 is a major air pollutant that can cause severe respiratory problems and ecosystem degradation due to acid rain formation [1], and industrial coal combustion is the main source of SO2 emissions. China's energy structure of "rich coal, lean oil, less gas" is difficult to change in the short term, and therefore SO2 emissions remain high [2,3]. As of 2015, the total emissions still exceeded 15 million tons [4]. Electricity, heat production, and metal smelting are the major industries that produce SO2 emissions [5]. Among them, coal-fired power plants generally use the limestone-gypsum method for wet flue gas desulfurization [6]. However, this desulfurization technology is a complicated process and requires a large area. Additionally, the product is desulfurized gypsum with low utilization value, which creates secondary pollution [7,8]. The chemical smelting industry often uses dry and semi-dry methods to recover SO2 in the form of sulfuric acid, but H2SO4 is inconvenient to transport as a highly corrosive liquid, and its current market supply is saturated [9–11]. In contrast, as an important basic chemical raw material, sulfur is widely used in the chemical industry, fertilizer industry, non-ferrous metal smelting, and military industries [12,13]. In addition, the production of high-performance functional materials, such as sulfide semiconductors, lithium-sulfur batteries, and sulfur-based mercury removal materials, depends on sulfur [14,15]. In summary, sulfur has broad market prospects and is the most ideal desulfurization product [16]. According to the National Bureau of Statistics of China, as of 2017, China’s sulfur import dependence was still as high as 65.8 %, with annual imports exceeding 10 million tons. If SO2 can be recycled in the form of sulfur, it can not only realize the resource recovery of desulfurization process, but also effectively alleviate the current shortage of China's sulfur resources. A reducing agent is required during the reduction of SO2 to elemental sulfur. Based on the reducing agent, desulfurization technology can be divided into carbothermal reduction [17], hydrogen reduction [18], methane reduction [19], and carbon monoxide reduction [20,21]. Studies on various types of reducing agents have been reported, in which the reduction temperature of carbon and CH4 is high, and many side reactions are difficult to avoid and control [22,23]. The source of H2 is limited, and the production cost of H2 is high. Fortunately, CO and SO2 coexist in flue gas with a wide range of sources, and the purity of elemental sulfur produced by reduction is high [24], which is considered the most promising agent for industrialization [25,26]. The reduction reaction must be carried out under the action of the catalyst to improve the reaction efficiency and reduce the reaction conditions. This has led to the development and selection of the catalyst becoming the focus of research. A composite catalyst of various metal oxides or sulfides has a synergistic effect. Rare earth metals have abundant surface oxygen vacancies, and the reaction follows a redox mechanism [18,27]. Supported catalysts are the focus of research. Common supports include molecular sieves, Al2O3, and SiO2 [28], and the loaded components are mainly transition metals. Wang et al. studied Fe2O3 supported on γ-Al2O3, HZSM-5, SiO2, and MgO, and found that Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 had the best performance [29]. Wang et al. supported eight metals, including Fe on CeO2, and found that the Fe2O3/CeO2 catalyst could effectively adsorb CO to reduce SO2, and had excellent activity and stability [30]. The noble metals Ru, Pt, and Au can also be used as active components for catalytic reduction desulfurization [31–33]. Blast furnace slag (BFS) is a byproduct of the steelmaking industry. The titanium-containing BFS can be used for pickling and extracting titanium metal or as a photocatalytic material. Low titanium BFS is currently only used as a building material additive for rough utilization [34,35]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop a scientific and viable new method for resource utilization of low-titanium BFS [36]. The main components of BFS are CaO, MgO, Al2O3, SiO2 (and TiO2), among which Al2O3, SiO2, and TiO2 are good catalyst supports. There have been studies on titanium-containing BFS for catalytic reduction desulfurization and denitrification [37], [38,39]. In order to avoid the wastage of resources, low titanium BFS was selected as the CaO-Al2O3-SiO2 composite support for resource desulfurization. It is more acidic than the single-supported catalyst surface and has a wider active temperature window. Numerous studies on desulfurization catalysts have been performed, but the use of precious metals and nanomaterials is generally cost-prohibitive. For transition metal-based catalysts, the critical role in the catalytic process is their sulfide phase rather than their oxidized phase, so a special presulfidation process is required before the reaction [26,28]. In addition, a large number of current studies focus on the desulfurization performance at a certain point in time and overall performance, and further research is needed on the catalytic reduction process and the reaction mechanism of the catalyst. In this study, iron-loaded catalysts based on BFS were prepared, evaluated, and characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray fluorescence (XRF), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). Furthermore, the reduction activity of SO2 with CO on the catalysts was studied. The present work mainly focused on the following: (1) Evaluating the performance of the catalysts in the CO-SO2 reaction. (2) Exploring the physical and chemical properties of the prepared catalysts. (3) Investigating the adsorbed species and probing the possible reduction mechanism of the CO-SO2 reaction through in situ DRIFTS studies. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The BFS was collected from an iron plant in Dezhou, Shandong Province, China. The preparation process of the Fe-BFS catalyst is shown in Fig. 1 . First, the BFS was ground into a fine powder to increase its specific surface area and improve the BFS activity. The finely ground BFS powder was poured into deionized water, stirred, and washed, and then solid-liquid separation was completed using a low-speed centrifuge. The washed BFS powder was placed in a dry box at 105 °C for drying. All the catalysts used in the experiments were supported by metal oxide catalysts prepared by an equal volume impregnation method. Based on relevant research results [29,40], the selected catalyst loading includes 10 wt.%, 15 wt.% and 20 wt.%. The water absorption rate of the BFS support was determined prior to preparation of the catalyst to determine the volume of deionized water used to dissolve the metal salt. The specific implementation method was as follows: the single-use amount of BFS support was determined, and the required Fe(NO3)3·9H2O was calculated, weighed, and dissolved in a certain amount of deionized water. After the nitrate was completely dissolved, the appropriate amount of BFS micropowder was added to the above solution and stirred evenly, and then it was shaken in an ultrasonic instrument for 1 h. The mixture was dried at 105 °C for 12–16 h in a dry box, and the catalyst precursor was placed in a tube furnace at 550 °C for 5 h under a N2 atmosphere. After cooling to room temperature, it was removed, and the tablet was sieved using 30–50 mesh to obtain the desired particle size. The catalyst preparation was completed. 2.2 Catalyst characterization XRD analysis was performed using an Ultima IV instrument. The diffraction curve was compared to the standard phase diffraction data in the PDF card to determine the crystal phase of the test sample. The sample was ground with a quartz mortar and the XRD pattern was recorded using an XRD diffractometer with a CuK α radiation source (λ = 0.154187 nm), a tube pressure of 40 kV, a current of 30 mA, and a scan angle of 2θ. The scanning range was from 10°–90°, and the scanning speed was 5°/min. The sample was subjected to XRF analysis using a Thermo Scientific 3600 spectrometer to determine the elemental and oxide content of the sample. The sample was subjected to XPS analysis using Thermo Fisher's Thermo ESCALAB 250XI to determine the elemental valence and molecular structure of the catalyst. In situ DRIFTS spectra were collected from 650 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1 at a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1 on a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrophotometer equipped with a high-sensitivity MCT detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. The catalyst (approximately 25 mg) was ground into a fine powder with a diameter of less than 2 μm and placed in a helium reaction cell to ensure that the surface level was as high as possible to enhance IR reflection. Prior to each reaction, the samples were pretreated in a stream of N2 at 400 °C for 1 h to eliminate physically adsorbed water and other impurities. The reaction temperature and holding time of the catalyst sample were set, the background spectra were collected at the target temperature, and then passed a specific concentration and a specific type of reaction gas of 60 mL/min. The infrared spectra were recorded under various target conditions by subtracting the corresponding background reference. 2.3 Evaluation of the catalyst activity The catalyst evaluation experiment for CO reduction of SO2 was performed using a fixed bed reaction system consisting of a gas distribution system, a reaction system, and a gas collection system. The experimental system is shown in Fig. 2 . The Beijing Qixing Huachuang mass flowmeter was used to accurately control the gas flow rate, and each type of gas was uniformly distributed by the gas mixing device. A custom quartz reactor d=12 mm and built-in porous sieve plate for catalyst particles (30–50 mesh) were used. The nitrogen was continuously purged to remove the moisture and impurities adsorbed on the catalyst surface during the increasing temperature phase before the activity evaluation started. The reaction gas entered from the upper portion of the reactor, and after the catalyst reduction reaction occurred, off-gas flowed out through the tail of the reactor. A sulfur condensation and collection device was used to facilitate observation of the reduced elemental sulfur crystals and prevent accumulation of sulfur powder in gas pipelines that may cause blockage. This required that the reactor behind the reaction zone and the gas pipeline between the reactor and the sulfur condensing device were well insulated to prevent sulfur vapor from condensing in advance. In addition, a water cooling device was added to the sulfur collection process, and a filter was installed at the outlet of the condensation device to prevent sulfur powder from further flowing out with the reaction gas. After condensing and sulfur collection, off-gas was collected using a gas collection bag, and gas composition analysis was performed using a gas chromatograph GC-7820 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame photometric detector (FPD) detector. The total intake gas volume was confirmed to be 300 mL/min, the gas volume composition was CO:SO2 = 2%:1%, and the remaining gas was N2。 The catalyst amount for each test was 3 g. The conversion rate of SO2 ( X S O 2 ), the selectivity of sulfur ( S s ), and the yield of elemental sulfur ( Y s ) are defined as follows: (1) X S O 2 = [ S O 2 ] i n - [ S O 2 ] o u t [ S O 2 ] i n × 100 % (2) S s = [ S O 2 ] i n - [ S O 2 ] o u t - C O S o u t - [ H 2 S ] o u t [ S O 2 ] i n - [ S O 2 ] o u t × 100 % (3) Y s = X S O 2 S s where [ S O 2 ] i n is the initial intake air concentration of SO2; [ S O 2 ] o u t , [ C O S ] o u t and [ H 2 S ] o u t are the gas concentrations of SO2, COS, and H2S in the exhaust gas after the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Evaluation of desulfurization activity of Fe2O3-BFS 3.1.1 Effect of temperature on catalytic activity The catalyst with 10 wt.% Fe2O3 loaded in BFS was selected. The total intake gas volume flow was 300 mL/min, and the space velocity was 6000 h−1. The activity evaluation experiments were conducted at three temperature points: 400 °C, 500 °C, and 600 °C. Each experiment lasted 2 h, and the gas after the reaction was collected using a gas collection bag every 20 min for qualitative and quantitative analysis of gas components. The catalytic performance and the concentration of sulfur-containing gas during the reaction at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4 . It can be seen from Fig. 3(a) that the catalyst had a relatively high SO2 conversion rate at the initial stage of the reaction, especially at 500 °C and 600 °C; the conversion rate of the catalyst reached 100 %. As the reaction time progresses, the catalyst conversion rate at 400 °C decreased linearly, and the conversion rate also began to decrease after 1 h at the start of the reaction at 500 °C. The downward trend until the end of the reaction was not smooth. The conversion rate of the catalyst at 600 °C was relatively stable, and the conversion rate of the catalyst was maintained above 90 % until the end of the reaction. Fig. 3(b) shows the change in sulfur selectivity of the catalyst at various temperatures. At 400 °C, due to the low reactivity, few by-products were formed and the selectivity was high. The 500 °C and 600 °C sulfur selectivity curves had similar trends. At the beginning of the reaction, because Fe2O3 had not been sulfided and lacked the necessary conditions for COS generation, the selectivity was very high. With the progress of the reaction, metal sulfides began to play a catalytic role, the by-products increased, and the sulfur selectivity decreased. When the concentration of COS stabilized at a certain value, the sulfur selectivity began to stabilize. The sulfur yield is a combination of conversion and selectivity. Fig. 4(a) shows the change in the concentration of sulfur-containing gas after the reaction of the BFS catalyst loaded with 10 wt.% Fe2O3 at 400 °C. According to the COS intermediate mechanism (specifically explained in 3.4.2), the production of COS also explains the extent of the reduction reaction to some extent. The content of COS was very low, and the content tended towards 0 as the reaction progressed, indicating that the activity of the reaction was not high. In addition, H2S also appeared in the exhaust gas, and its content gradually decreased as the reaction progressed. H2S and COS were also observed at 500 °C and 600 °C. Particularly at 600 °C, the catalyst activity was high, and the concentration of sulfur-containing by-products was large. In general, the performance of the catalyst at 600 °C was the best, but the high conversion was at the cost of high concentration of by-product gases. The higher the reaction temperature, the greater the energy consumption, but this is not conducive to the occurrence of the reaction and industrialization. Therefore, 500 °C was selected as the reaction temperature for further optimization. 3.1.2 Effect of catalyst loading on catalytic activity According to the above experimental results, 500 °C was selected as the uniform reaction temperature, and the catalyst loading was 10 wt.% Fe2O3, 15 wt.% Fe2O3 and 20 wt.% Fe2O3 for activity evaluation experiments. The changes in the catalytic performance and sulfur-containing gas concentration in the reaction process under different catalyst loadings are shown in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 . Taking the conversion rate in Fig. 5(a) as the evaluation index, the performance of the catalyst with 15 wt.% Fe2O3 was stable, and the conversion rate in 2 h was maintained above 95 %. The catalyst loaded with 20 wt.% Fe2O3 experienced a decline in the conversion rate after 1 h. This was because the active phase of the catalyst was FeSx [41], and the oxide in the catalyst needed to be sulfided into an active phase after a period of time. Compared with 10 wt.% and 15 wt.%, the 20 wt.% loading was deemed excessive, causing a blocked stack of loaded components at the pores and insufficient contact with the SO2. Therefore, it took more reaction time to complete the sulfurization of Fe2O3. The high conversion rate at the initial stage of the reaction may be the adsorption of the BFS itself, which needs to be confirmed by subsequent characterization. In addition, because BFS is a byproduct produced during high-temperature steelmaking, its specific surface area and surface void structure are not well developed. Excessive loading will stack the surface pores and reduce the specific surface area and active sites. With the selectivity of sulfur as the evaluation index, the byproduct increased with the reaction time, and the selectivity decreased, but the upward trend slowed with the reaction time. Catalysts with 15 wt.% Fe2O3 and 20 wt.% Fe2O3 are similar in catalytic performance. The loading had a significant effect on the performance improvement of the catalyst. The loading increased from 10 wt.% to 15 wt.%, and the conversion rate and sulfur yield increased by more than 30 %. However, from 15 wt.% to 20 wt.%, the catalytic performance did not change significantly, even though the activation time increased. Excessive loading may also have a negative impact on the surface structure and decrease the catalytic activity. Fig. 6 shows the change in sulfide gas concentration after the reaction of BFS catalysts with 15 wt.% Fe2O3 and 20 wt.% Fe2O3 at 500 °C. The concentration changes of the byproduct gases H2S and COS of the two catalysts are similar 1 h before the reaction. After 80 min of reaction, the SO2 and COS concentrations showed a significant difference: the SO2 concentration of 15 wt.% Fe2O3 was very low, and a large amount of COS was produced at the same time. However, the SO2 concentration of the 20 wt.% Fe2O3 catalyst was nearly 700 ppm, and the concentration of COS was low. This also indicates that the active phase of the 15 wt.% Fe2O3 catalyst is more fully developed and the catalyst activity is higher. 3.1.3 Effect of space velocity on catalytic activity The BFS catalyst loaded with 15 wt.% Fe2O3 was used to evaluate the activity at 500 °C under the conditions of space velocity at 6000 h−1, 12 000 h−1 and 18 000 h−1, and the conversion and the concentration change of the main by-product COS were compared. It can be seen from Fig. 7 that the space velocity has a significant influence on the performance of the catalyst. When the space velocity was 6000 h−1, the conversion rate was maintained above 95 %, and as the reaction proceeded, metal sulfides were formed, and the concentration of COS increased. When the space velocity was 12 000 h−1, the performance of the first 1 h was acceptable because of the adsorption of SO2 by the BFS, and the SO2 conversion rate dropped rapidly after 1 h. At the same time, the concentration of COS decreased. When the space velocity was 18 000 h−1, the activity of the catalyst was very low. According to the change in sulfide gas concentration in the exhaust gas, there was almost no COS production in the late stage of the reaction, indicating that the amount of active metal phase FeSx on the catalyst was too small and the catalytic effect was very limited. 3.2 Catalytic activity characterization 3.2.1 XRD and XRF XRD and XRF analyses of the BFS micropowder raw material and the catalyst before and after the reaction are presented in Fig. 8 and Table 1 . The phase composition of the BFS micropowder material is amorphous [42], and there is only a distinct diffraction peak within 20–40°, and no other crystal phase diffraction peaks are observed. The supported active component Fe2O3 was highly dispersed on the catalyst support. At the same time, owing to the glass phase characteristics of the BFS support, the crystallinity of the active component is so small that the detection limit of the instrument is not reached. Therefore, no obvious Fe2O3 diffraction peak or diffraction peak after iron oxide sulfidation appeared on the surface of the catalyst before and after the reaction. In addition, there is a very obvious CaSO4 diffraction peak (ICDD-PDF#72−0916). The XRF results also show that there is a large amount of sulfur on the catalyst after the reaction, indicating that the absorption of SO2 on the BFS is strong and irreversible. At the same time, owing to the inadequate load caused by the unavoidable container residue during operation and the underdeveloped pore structure of BFS, the actual loading is lower than the calculated loading. Combined with the catalytic performance and the sulfide gas concentration of the 15 wt.% Fe2O3-BFS furnace BFS catalyst during the reaction process, it can be inferred that SO2 is directly adsorbed by alkaline calcium oxide or calcium salt in the BFS at the initial stage of the reaction. Since the adsorption of BFS is strong, the initial conversion rate of the reaction reaches 100 %. The formation of FeSx requires a sulfidation process for a period of time, and the active phase in the early stage of the reaction does not have much effect; therefore there is no substantial intermediate product COS formation. As the reaction proceeds, the metal oxide is sulfided, which reacts with CO. According to the COS intermediate mechanism, the by-product COS begin to form in large quantities. The change in the concentration of SO2 is the result of both adsorption and reduction modes, which allows the BFS catalyst to be used without prior sulfidation, simplifying the reaction process. 3.2.2 XPS XPS analysis of 15 wt.% Fe2O3-BFS catalyst before and after the reaction was performed to investigate the valence distribution and change of Fe and S elements on the catalyst. The characterization results are shown in Fig. 9 . The prepared catalysts contain doublet Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 with binding energies of 711 eV and 724 eV, respectively [43]. In addition, a satellite peak appears at approximately 719 eV, which is the main feature of Fe3+ in γ-Fe2O3, which proves that the metal supported in the catalyst before the reaction exists in the form of Fe2O3 [44]. The satellite peak at 719 eV disappears after the reaction, demonstrating that Fe3+ in the catalyst is reduced to Fe2+. In addition, it was found that the catalyst produced strong magnetism in the experiment, indicating that some of the Fe3+ and Fe2+ forms Fe3O4. Fe2+ is present in the FeS, which is the active phase of the reduction reaction. The analysis of elemental sulfur is shown in Fig. 9(b). Before the reaction, only one peak appears on the surface of the catalyst, and the binding energy is about 169 eV, corresponding to the S6+ in the oxidation state, which exists in the form of sulfate [45]. The intensity of the peak at this point is small, and according to the XRF characterization results, this is the sulfur-containing component in the BFS itself. The sulfur species of the catalyst after catalytic reduction has two valence states, namely S2− species with a binding energy of about 162 eV and SO4 2− species with a binding energy of about 169 eV [46,47]. The peak intensity at 169 eV is large, indicating that a large number of sulfate species are formed, and S2- is present in FeS. 3.3 In-situ DRIFTS characterization of catalysts 3.3.1 SO2 adsorption and desorption experiments To explore the dynamic adsorption process of SO2 on the catalyst, an in-situ DRIFTS study of SO2 adsorption and desorption on 15 wt.% Fe2O3-BFS was conducted. The obtained spectrum is shown in Fig. 10 . The strong peak at 1360 cm−1 is SO2 in the gas phase, and the strength remains basically stable with the increase in adsorption time [28]. After fully adsorbing for 80 min at 200 °C, the peak disappeared after N2 purging. The peak at 1250 cm−1 is attributed to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of SO2 adsorbed on the catalyst, and the peak remains unchanged after N2 purging. The presence of SO2 in the adsorbed phase also indicates the presence of an active reaction intermediate (SO bond) on the catalyst, demonstrating that SO2 has been successfully activated [48]. The small peak at 1400–1600 cm−1 is attributed to the Al2O3 component in the BFS adsorbing SO2 [49]. The band centered at 3306 cm−1 is attributed to the hydrogen bonding of SO2 to the surface hydroxyl group, thereby producing H2O, which also explains the stretching vibration mode of water occurring at 1640 cm-1 [50,51]. The negative band at 3732 cm−1 is a reaction between SO2 and OH, which consumes hydroxyl groups. The energy band at 2300 cm−1 is a strong H bond between the SO2 and Brønsted positions [50,52]. The peak does not disappear after N2 purging, indicating that the adsorption of SO2 on the BFS is strong and irreversible. From the above analyses, it is known that during the adsorption process, the surface hydroxyl groups of the catalyst and the SO2 hydrogen bond combine to produce H2O. The formation of water vapor can help explain the appearance of the byproduct H2S. The specific reaction paths are discussed in the following section. 3.3.2 CO adsorption desorption experiment To explore the dynamic adsorption process of CO on the catalyst, an in-situ DRIFTS study of CO adsorption and desorption on 15 wt.% Fe2O3-BFS was performed. The obtained spectrum is shown in Fig. 11 . In the adsorption experiments at 200 °C, two peaks are observed at 2173 cm−1 and 2120 cm−1, representing the CO in the gas phase, which are the P and R branches of gaseous CO, respectively [53]. The peaks disappear after N2 purging. A band is observed at 2300–2400 cm−1 due to physical adsorption or formation of gaseous CO2 [54]. Fe3+ is reduced to Fe2+ under a CO atmosphere, releasing oxygen vacancies, and CO on the catalyst surface is oxidized to CO2 [55,56]. The longer the time that the CO is introduced, the greater the amount of CO2 produced. CO2 can be adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, so the peak does not disappear with N2 purging. When the reaction temperature is increased to 400 °C, the number of peaks are found to be the same as that at 200 °C, but the intensity of the peaks is less due to desorption of the physically adsorbed gas at a high temperature. Combined with the above characterization of the adsorption process of SO2 and CO, it can be reasonably concluded that the catalyst adsorbs a large amount of SO2, and the amount of CO adsorbed is negligible. The gas-phase CO is not adsorbed on the catalyst surface but directly reacts with the adsorbed SO2 [57]. 3.3.3 CO + SO2 co-adsorption experiment In order to explore the reaction mechanism of SO2 reduction, an in-situ DRIFTS study of SO2+CO co-adsorption was conducted to study the evolution of surface species during the dynamic reaction. Fig. 12 shows the spectrum of SO2+CO co-adsorption at different temperatures. The symmetric stretching of monodentate sulfite is 850–940 cm−1 [52], whereas 1150 cm−1, 1225 cm−1 are the stretching vibrations of surface-adsorbed bidentate sulfate [58,59], and 1206 cm−1 is the anti-symmetric stretching of SO of physically adsorbed SO2 [50]. It is generally considered that the bands formed at 600–1500 cm−1 are generally attributed to the formation and adsorption of various types of sulfates [60,61]. Since there are many components in the BFS, more types of sulfates are formed, and more adsorption peaks appear. The two peaks at 975 cm−1 and 1078 cm−1 show opposite growth trends: a negative peak appeared at 975 cm−1 at 30 min, and a positive peak appeared at 1078 cm−1 at the same time, indicating that the emergence of the latter is at the expense of the consumption of the former. The peak intensities at 870 cm−1 and 1015 cm−1 are large, which may be due to the adsorption reaction of SO2 and calcium oxide. The appearance of a negative peak is generally considered to be the re-reaction consumption of the forming substances (sulfite and sulfate). Since the reaction temperature was high and the resolution was severe, no significant SO2 adsorption peak was observed. The 2000–2500 cm−1 zone mainly represents the CO reaction zone. Unlike simple CO adsorption, the gas phase CO peak at 2173 cm−1 is clearly weakened and the CO2 peak intensity is increased. There are two sources of CO2: one is the reduction of Fe2O3 by CO, which can also be observed in pure CO adsorption; the other is that CO reacts with metal sulfides to form COS, and COS further reduces SO2 to produce CO2. Only the peaks of the adsorption of SO2 (1240 cm−1, 1360 cm−1) and CO (2120 cm−1, 2173 cm−1) are observed at 300 °C. At this time, the reaction temperature is too low, and SO2 is firmly adsorbed on the carrier and the metal oxide, occupying most of the oxygen vacancies. CO can hardly reduce Fe3+ to form the active phase of FeSx, which further blocks the SO2 and COS reaction, so there are no adsorption peaks for CO2. This indicates that the catalyst does not play a catalytic role, and the reduction reaction does not occur. The appearance of a negative peak may be caused by a small amount of CO2 produced being absorbed by the BFS to form a carbonate. The carbonate peak was not observed as it disappeared at 250 °C [55]. 3.4 15 % Fe2O3-BFS catalytic reaction mechanism for SO2 reduction by CO 3.4.1 Catalyst life test 15 wt.% Fe2O3-BFS catalyst was selected, and the reaction temperature was set to 500 °C. The experiment was continued for 12 h. The SO2 conversion of the catalyst and the change in the COS concentration in the exhaust gas are shown in Fig. 13 . As can be seen from Fig. 13, the deactivation of the catalyst does not occur suddenly at a certain time point, but the catalyst is gradually poisoned and loses its activity with the introduction of the SO2 reaction gas. The entire reaction process can be divided into four stages according to the conversion rate of the catalyst and the change in the concentration of COS. The first stage occurs during the first 40 min, during which no COS is generated, and the conversion rate is close to 100 %. This is because the active phase of the catalyst has not yet formed and cannot react with CO to form COS. The BFS support strongly adsorbs SO2. The second stage is from 40 to 180 min. A large amount of COS is produced in this stage, and the conversion rate is close to 100 %, which is the period when the catalyst exerts its catalytic effect to the greatest extent. At this time, the metal oxide was successfully sulfided, the active phase appeared and reacted with CO to form COS, and COS further reacted with SO2 to form elemental sulfur. The third stage is from 180 to 280 min. The concentration of COS begins to decrease, while the conversion rate is still close to 100 %. At this time, the catalyst showed a slight sulfur poisoning. The reduction of the oxygen-containing active sites on the surface hinders the sulfurization process, and the COS content decreases. However, the remaining active sites are still sufficient to support high conversion rates. The fourth stage occurred after 280 min. The concentration of COS and the conversion rate of SO2 continue to decrease at the same time. This is a process in which the catalyst is continuously poisoned and the active site is continuously reduced. The stable sulfate species appeared on the catalyst surface, causing an irreversible poisoning reaction until the catalyst was completely deactivated. 3.4.2 Reaction mechanism of SO2 reduction by CO Analysis of the sulfate in the CO + SO2 co-adsorption in the in-situ DRIFTS study and the CaSO4 diffraction peaks in the XRD pattern showed that BFS had a strong adsorption capacity for SO2, especially for the calcium oxide. Therefore, adsorption desulfurization could be quickly exerted after the introduction of SO2. The reaction of CO and SO2 underwent the sulfidation of Fe2O3, the formation process of COS, and the process of COS reduction to form elemental sulfur. Specifically, the CO + SO2 reaction followed both the redox mechanism and the COS intermediate mechanism with the catalyst [62–64]. The redox mechanism is mainly followed in the initial stage of the reaction to produce a sulfide phase of the metal oxide, and the strong adsorption and the redox reaction path simultaneously result in a high conversion rate. As the reaction progressing, FeSx is gradually formed, and the concentration of COS in the reaction gas increases. At the same time, owing to the limited CaO and adsorption sites, the adsorption of SO2 is weakened. At this point, the reaction follows both the redox reaction route and COS intermediate route. The redox reaction pathway is mainly responsible for providing metal sulfides with the participation of oxygen vacancies, while the COS intermediate pathway takes the dominant position in the reaction and completes the resource recovery of elemental sulfur. Reaction route 1 (proposed redox reaction mechanism) is described as follows: (4) CO + Fe2O2[O]-BFS→CO2+Fe2O2[]-BFS (5) Fe2O2[]-BFS + SO2→Fe2O2[O]-BFS+[SO] (6) Fe2O2[]-BFS+[SO]→Fe2O2[O]-BFS + S* (7) Fe2O2[]-BFS + S→Fe2O2S-BFS (8) Fe2O[]S-BFS + S→Fe2OS2-BFS (9) Fe2[]S2-BFS + S→Fe2S3-BFS where [O] represents the lattice oxygen and [] represents the oxygen vacancies. The lattice oxygen in the catalyst is taken up by CO to form CO2 and forms oxygen vacancies on the catalyst, which is the active center of the catalyst. Then, the oxygen vacancies react with SO2 to form elemental sulfur, and the catalyst containing oxygen vacancies will also react with S to form Fe2O2S. The catalyst is then sulfided. The reaction continues and the lattice oxygen of the metal oxide continues to be captured, producing species such as Fe2S3. Reaction route 2 (proposed COS intermediate reaction mechanism) is described as follows: (10) Fe2S3+CO→2FeS + COS (11) 2COS + SO2→3S+2CO2 The total response can be expressed as: (12) 2CO + SO2 = 2CO2+S Reactions (4)–(9) dominate in the early stages of the reaction, at which time the catalyst desulfurization activity is not high. Correspondingly, the catalysts under the three loadings of 10 wt.%, 15 wt.%, and 20 wt.% have no by-product COS at this time, and the catalyst selectivity is very high. With the appearance of metal sulfides, reactions (10) and (11) begin to play a role. At this time, owing to the small loading, 10 wt.% Fe2O3-BFS has limited metal sulfide formation, and the conversion rate gradually decreases. However, the other two catalysts maintain high activity under the simultaneous action of the two reaction paths, generating a large amount of COS gas and element sulfur are recovered. A possible mechanism for SO2 reduction by CO is shown in Fig. 14 . The production of H2S byproduct was observed in the reaction due to the reaction of SO2 with the surface hydroxyl groups of the catalyst to form H2O. However, the catalyst remained active during the appearance of H2S, indicating that the catalyst had a certain water resistance, and H2O would not change the surface structure of the catalyst. Any water produced would be quickly consumed by COS hydrolysis, Claus reverse reaction, or water-gas shift reaction. During the experiment, the concentration of SO2 increased slightly with the increase in H2S concentration in the catalyst with 10 wt.% Fe2O3 and 15 wt.% Fe2O3, and the conversion rate decreased. In addition, the formation of H2S and COS tended to increase simultaneously, and the selectivity of elemental sulfur decreased. However, the regularity was not strong overall, and the production of H2S might be the result of several reactions. The possible reaction paths are as follows [65]: (13) SO2+2OH→SO3+H2O (14) SO3→SO3 2−→SO4 2- (1) Claus reverse reaction: (15) 2S+2H2O→2H2S + SO2 This will result in an increase in the steady-state SO2 concentration while reducing the selectivity of elemental sulfur. (2) Hydrolysis of COS: (16) COS+H2O→H2S + CO2 This reaction reduces the COS concentration while increasing H2S. (3) Water gas shift reaction: (17) CO+H2O→H2+CO2 This reaction consumes the reducing agent CO, resulting in a decrease in SO2 conversion. The generated H2 may react with SO2 or react with elemental sulfur to reduce the sulfur yield: (18) H2+S→H2S Thermodynamic calculations of Okay and Short indicated that the water gas shift reaction can occur under the reaction conditions used [66]. 4 Conclusions In this study, environmentally friendly and efficient iron-loaded catalysts were successfully prepared from BFS. Through a series of comprehensive characterizations, the physical and chemical properties of the prepared catalyst were systematically studied, and the catalytic reaction pathway in the CO-SO2 reaction was further proposed. The optimal reaction conditions obtained through the activity evaluation experiment are as follows: The Fe2O3 loading amount is 15 wt.%, the reaction temperature is 500 °C, and the space velocity is 6000 h−1. At this time, the SO2 conversion rate is stable above 95 % within 2 h, and the average sulfur yield can reach 80 % or more. However, the conversion rate continues to decline until it is completely deactivated. Therefore, regeneration of the catalyst needs to be investigated in future research. The reaction follows the redox mechanism and the COS intermediate product mechanism. The redox reaction path sulfides the metal oxide to produce a catalytically active phase, and metal sulfides participate in reactions in the COS intermediate pathway. There are a large number of sulfates of the catalyst after the reaction under the dual effects of adsorption and reduction. These sulfates reduce the number of surface active sites and deactivate the catalyst. SO2 reacts with the surface hydroxyl groups of the BFS to form H2O, which in turn produces H2S as a byproduct. However, the formation of H2S did not significantly affect the catalytic activity, indicating that the catalyst has a certain water resistance. coredata.dc:description: For realizing resource desulfurization and high-value sulfur recovery, an iron-loaded catalyst was prepared from steelmaking byproduct blast furnace slag to reduce SO2 to elemental sulfur with CO. SO2 conversion efficiency, sulfur selectivity, and sulfur yield were used to evaluate the catalyst behavior. The catalyst with 15wt.% Fe2O3 at 500 °C showed the best activity performance. The changes in the structure and active phase of the catalyst as well as the complete reaction pathway were explored. A series of in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy experiments were used to study the adsorption and desorption processes of CO and SO2, and a large number of sulfates were formed on the catalyst surface after the reaction. Combined with the experimental performance, the strong adsorption of BFS and the production pathway of H2S were proposed. The prepared iron-loaded catalysts followed the redox mechanism and the COS intermediate mechanism in the reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic performance and reaction mechanism of an iron-loaded catalyst derived from blast furnace slag for the CO-SO2 reaction to produce sulfur
